polls, that, "In an illegitimate
undemocratic system, a vote

the further legitimization of the
system."

MacKay Scores S.D.S.
Alan MacKay, National Chairman of Young Americans for
Freedom, has asked American students to ignore the boycott of the
November 5 elections planned by Students for a Democratic
Society.
"SDS is continually attempting to subsitute violent upheaval
as opposed to progress and problem-solving. We in YAF continue to
believe that the American system and its political process offer the
Optimum framework for solving social problems withing the context
of a free system. I urge students across the nation to ignore the SDS
boycott of the November 5 elections, and to practice 'participatory
democracy.'

Students Fast In Protest
Charles Palmer, president of the Associated Students of the
University of California, and Konstantin, editor-in-chief of the Daily
Californian, the student newspaper at Berkeley, announced at a news
conference on Monday that they had begun to fast.
"We see the University pressured by politicians and many
people of the state, repressed by the Regents in open disregard for
faculty autonomy and further weakened by student apathy and
faculty evasion."
Palmer further stated that "we feel we have
exhausted, through petition and peaceful protest, the regular
Channels of appeal. We also reject, at this time, violent action as a
reasonable and democratic tool of change."
When he was asked to specify some act that would indicate to
them that their fast was successful, Palmer said:
"A statement by Governor (Ronald) Reagan that he will cease
and desist his political attacks on the University."

"Freedom and Dissent" Offered
"Freedom and Dissent," a course which will examine the
concepts of civil disobedience and freedom of speech, will be offered
by the Department of Philosophy next semester.
Dr. Harry Silverstein, who is teaching the course, listed some
of the topics to be considered as: free speech and its relation to
national security; the problems of censorship; and the distinctions
between violence and non-violence. "The morality of breaking the
law" may be a topic as well as "how much freedom is permissable by
the government."
The course will be accompanied by a series of public lectures.
According to Dr. Silverstein the "speakers were chosen with the
hope of getting varied points of view on the problems inherent in the
current question of freedom and dissent."
The speakers will include Dr. Noam Chomsky, professor of
liguistics at MIT; Mr. M.I. Leibman, Chicago attorney; Dr. C.H.
Prichett, professor of political science at the University of Chicago;
and Dr. M.O. Sibley, political science professor at the University of
Minnesota.

Kaffke Seen as CIA Agent
(CPS) - San Francisco State's Experimental College (EC) has
denied teaching privileges to a man suspected of being a CIA agent.
The man, Roberto Kaffke, taught a course on guerrilla warfare
last year and planned to teach one called "Philosophy and
Revolution" this year. The official reason he was denied permission
to teach the course was "lack of discipline and trustworthiness."
But many students say the real reason is an alleged phone call
from a federal agency to a university dean offering to pay off debts
Kaffke owes the college. The dean denies he received such a call and
Kaffke says it was a smear designed to get him out of the EC, but
the rumor persists on the campus.
Kaffke aroused some controversy for teaching his course last
year, evoking criticism from Mac Rafferty, California's
arch-conservative state superintendent of public instruction and now
the Republican candidate for the U.S. Senate.

The Hopkins chapter of the Students for a Democratic Society
has recently applied for funds to the Student Activities Committee
(SAC).
Mr. Robert Bilgrave, Director of Student Affairs, stated that
he felt SDS would face little difficulties if procedures are followed.
Bilgrave did indicate that SDS must submit, with the other student

Dr. Wilson H. Elkins, President of the University of Maryland,

campus."
He state further that the SDS is "no good, and they have no
regard for law and order. Their aim ... is anarchy; in that state they
would emerge the dictators."

To the Editors:
The October 18th issue of the
News-Letter presented articles and
an editorial which questioned the
University's relationship to the
ROTC program and further
sought to examine various aspects
of the program. With an imposing
collection of "facts," the
News-Letter's writers attempted
to demonstrate, in effect, that the
ROTC program is not compatable
with modern liberal thought (as
expressed week after week in the
News-Letter) and therefore is
detrimental to the campus
community. In brief, the
News-Letter has challenged the
right of ROTC to exist on campus
and for interested students to
have access to such a program.
A point by point refutation
and correction of the "facts" in
the News-Letter's articles would
take up far more room than the
originals: we must leave it to the
dicerning reader to use his
intelligence in interpreting the
News-Letter's writings. In essence,
however, the conclusion that the
articles are mostly a collection of
half- truths and distortions is
valid. The few accurate facts
quoted are those which serve the
purposes of the writers and which
give their work an aura of
authenticity and legitimacy.
Several particular items in the
News-Letter's verbal barrage are
so noxious that some comment is
required. The first is Mr.
Sakowich's "woeful Rotsy Tale."
This Tale would be a delightful
piece of fantasy written in an
amusing style were it not that it is
presented as a factual narrative.
When the Tale is stripped of its
innuendoes and clever phrases, the
basic issue appears. Because the
government cancelled his ROTC
scholarship, Mr. Sakowich
apparently finds it necessary to
"grind an axe" with ROTC, and
the News-Letter permits itself to
be used as a forum for this sort of
vindictiveness. What Mr. Sakowich
does not tell us is that his record
in ROTC was so dismally poor
that if it were to be printed, it
would prove a source of actute
embarrassment to both Mr.
Sakowich and the News-Letter. It
is therefore suprising that the
News-Letter and Mr. Sakowich
consider themselves qualified to
become the judges and critics of
the ROTC program.
Another of the particularly
noxious points concerns what the
News-Letter called "a
self-imposed inequality,"
particularly relating to enrollment

and matriculation. ROTC is not
really unique in this respect when,
in fact, most of the major
departments have established their
own standards of matriculation
and course pre-requisites. Since
ROTC is completely voluntary,
these are accepted by the
participating student as he would
accept the pre-requisites and
requirements in other courses and
departments.
We further challenge the
investigation committee suggested
by the News-Letter's editorial.
The ROTC program does not
interfere with free inquiry, with
the pursuit of knowledge, nor
with any other manifestation
which are to be expected in a
University atmosphere. ROTC
does not in any way affect the
student who does not choose to
participate in the program. It is of
great benefit to that student who
is interested in the objectives of
ROTC. Consequently, non-cadets
have no right to interfere in a
program in which they have, bY
choice, no role and which does
them no ill. Any critiquing should
be done by cadets, Army
instructors, and others specificallY
interested in the betterment of
the ROTC program. The small
amount of credit previously
awarded for ROTC participation
(approximately 1 hour of credit
for three hours of attendance) Is
equal to the credit given to the
laboratores in the basic sciences.
Yet some of these laboratories,
frequently taught by graduate
instructors with little interest in
what they are teaching, fall below
the caliber of many courses
offered at Hopkins.
It is, we suppose, to be
expected that such articles and
editorials will appear in a
"newspaper" such as the
News-Letter. We can only suggest
that the News-Letter put its own
house in order before criticizing
others who have far less injurious
effects on the Hopkins
community.

"Freedom and Dissent," a course which will examine the
concepts of civil disobedience and freedom of speech, will be offered

Prichett, professor of political science at the University of Chicago;

Minnesota.
